questions.text: The true statement regarding central chemoreceptors is?

choices.text: Detects H+ in brain interstitial fluid
Located above the surface of the ventrolateral medulla

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Detects H+ in brain interstitial fluid

 

Explanation:

The central chemoreceptors detect H+ in brain interstitial fluid.

Central chemoreceptors:

 

 

Details

Location

Bilaterally below (Option C ruled out) the surface of the ventrolateral medulla, immediately caudal to the pontomedullary junction.

Synonyms

  • Medullary chemoreceptors.
  • Chemosensitive areas.

Mechanism of Stimulation

Arterial PCO2 increases

↓

H+ ions in the brain interstitial fluid increases.

↓

Central chemoreceptors get stimulated to increase respiration (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the J receptor reflex except?

choices.text: They are located near the pulmonary capillaries.
Activation of J receptors causes rapid breathing.
They are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs.
They are exclusively involved in regulating airway smooth muscle tone.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) They are exclusively involved in regulating airway smooth muscle tone

 

Explanation:

J-receptor reflex:

  • The pulmonary C fibres are located adjacent to the alveoli and are accessible from the pulmonary capillary circulation (Option A ruled out)
  • They are also called juxtapulmonary capillary or J receptors (described by Indian scientist Dr A. S. Paintal).
  • The pulmonary C fibres are more sensitive to mechanical processes like edema, congestion, embolism, and intravenous or intracardiac administration of chemicals like capsaicin P.
  • Effect: On stimulation, they cause rapid shallow breathing, bronchoconstriction, increased airway secretion, and cardiovascular depression. (Option B ruled out)
  • Acute stimulation results in apnea and a marked hypotension.
  • Skeletal muscle tone is also abruptly reduced.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is undergoing a respiratory assessment in the clinic. The patient is asked to take a deep breath and hold it for an extended period. During this maneuver, the clinician observes that the patient’s inspiratory phase extends rather than transitioning to expiration. Which reflex is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Head's paradoxical reflex

 

Explanation:

In this scenario, the observation of prolonged inspiration extending rather than transitioning to expiration suggests the involvement of Head’s paradoxical reflex.

 

Head's paradoxical reflex:

Aspect

Details

Receptors

Rapidly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors (RARs)

Response

Brief burst of action potentials in response to lung inflation

Feedback Mechanism

Enhances inspiration, especially during vagus nerve recovery

Clinical Significance

Initiates first breath in newborns, generates augmented breaths, prevents lung collapse

Implications

Relevant for respiratory physiology, neonatal resuscitation, and respiratory control mechanisms

 

Cough reflex (Option C) is triggered by irritation in the airways. It involves a sudden, forceful expulsion of air from the lungs to clear the airways of irritants or obstructions.

 

Sneeze reflex (Option D) rapidly expulses air from the lungs to clear nasal passages. It is triggered by irritation in the nasal passages and involves a deep inspiration followed by a forceful exhalation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the receptor for Herring-Breur reflexes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pulmonary stretch receptors

 

Explanation:

  • Hering and Breuer in 1868 found that lung inflation decreases tidal volume and increases respiratory frequency.
  • There are two Hering- Breuer reflexes: Hering-Breuer inflation & deflation reflexes.

 

Hering-Breuer inflation reflex:

  • Steady increase in lung volume (lung inflation) results in an increase in the duration of expiration.
  • Receptors: Slowly adapting
  • Marked inflation of the lungs with sustained pressure may even abruptly terminate inspiration in progress, prolonging expiration.

 

Hering-Breuer deflation reflex:

  • Marked deflation of the lung results in a decrease in expiration duration.
  • As described above, the receptors are slowly adapting stretch receptors in the lung parenchyma and airways, and the vagus nerve provides the afferent and efferent pathways.

 

Significance of Hering-Breuer Reflex:

  • It protects the lung from overinflation while marinating normal alveolar ventilation.
  • It is more useful in infants than in adults.
  • It controls tidal volume during eupnea (normal breathing) in infants.
  • This reflex does not operate in adults unless the tidal volume is much greater than the normal inspiration.
  • Especially in the awake state in adults, this reflex is overwhelmed by more prominent central control.

questions.text: What happens if a person inhales a gas mixture containing 5% carbon dioxide (CO2) during voluntary hyperventilation?

choices.text: The person will experience a significant drop in arterial PCO2, leading to apnea.
The person will maintain a normal arterial PCO₂ and prevent respiratory alkalosis.
The person will experience increased alveolar and arterial PCO2, preventing apnea.
The person will experience decreased ventilation due to the stimulation of medullary chemoreceptors.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The person will experience increased alveolar and arterial PCO₂, preventing apnea.

 

Explanation: 

Physiological Change

Description

Increase in Alveolar CO₂
  • Inhalation of 5% CO₂ increases the alveoli's partial pressure of CO₂ (PCO₂).
  • Elevated alveolar PCO₂ leads to an increase in arterial PCO₂.

Stimulation of Ventilation
  • A rise in arterial PCO₂ stimulates the medullary chemoreceptors.
  • This results in an increase in ventilation (hyperventilation continues) to eliminate excess CO₂.

Avoidance of Apnea
  • Without additional CO₂, hyperventilation-induced hypocapnia can lead to apnea (temporary cessation of breathing).
  • Inhaling 5% CO₂ prevents a significant drop in arterial PCO₂, avoiding apnea.

Maintaining Blood pH
  • Inhaled CO₂ helps maintain blood pH closer to normal by preventing respiratory alkalosis.
  • This balance is crucial to avoid adverse effects on cellular and enzymatic functions.

New Equilibrium
  • A new equilibrium is established with slightly elevated alveolar and arterial PCO₂.
  • The person continues to hyperventilate as long as CO₂ is inhaled.

 

The person will experience a significant drop in arterial PCO2, leading to apnea (Option A):

  • This happens during pure hyperventilation without CO₂ enrichment, where excessive CO₂ loss leads to hypocapnia.

  • But in this case, the inhaled 5% CO₂ offsets the drop in CO₂.

  • So, arterial PCO₂ remains closer to normal, and apnea is avoided.

The person will maintain a normal arterial PCO₂ and prevent respiratory alkalosis (Option B):

  • If 5% CO₂ were added without hyperventilation, then yes, arterial PCO₂ would rise.

  • But during hyperventilation, the tendency is for CO₂ to fall.

  • Inhaling 5% CO₂ during hyperventilation only normalizes PCO₂, it does not raise it above normal.

The person will experience decreased ventilation due to the stimulation of medullary chemoreceptors (Option D):

  • Medullary chemoreceptors increase ventilation in response to high PCO₂.

  • A 5% CO₂ mix would stimulate respiration, not suppress it.

  • Also, voluntary hyperventilation is being done, so central control is overriding automatic regulation.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does the sensitivity of chemoreceptors decrease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Emphysema

 

Explanation:

Emphysema impairs chemoreceptor function, affecting respiratory drive, increasing dyspnea, and causing potential complications.

 

Impaired Chemoreceptor Function:

  • ↓ Detection of gas exchange abnormalities
  • ↓ Response to CO₂ levels

 

Consequence

Description

Complications

Dyspnea

Difficulty breathing due to impaired chemoreceptor function

Occurs even with non-critically abnormal blood gas levels

Acidosis and Mental Status Changes

Respiratory acidosis from inadequate CO₂ expulsion

Mental status changes, need for ventilatory support

Ventilation-
Perfusion Mismatch

Mismatch due to structural lung changes reduced compensatory mechanism

Complicates breathing regulation

 

Asthma (Option B) generally increases chemoreceptor sensitivity due to intermittent hypoxia and hypercapnia.

 

Acute bronchitis (Option C) is often associated with increased respiratory irritability and sensitivity.

 

Pulmonary fibrosis (Option D) can lead to hypoxia and increased sensitivity of chemoreceptors, though the overall impact on sensitivity can vary.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence regarding the mechanism of activation of a glomus cell:


	Depolarisation
	Calcium influx
	Reduced K+ conductance
	Increased ventilation
	Dopamine release
questions.solution:
​​​​​​Correct Answer: B) 3, 1, 2, 5, 4

 

Explanation:

  1. Reduced K+ Conductance:
    • Under hypoxic conditions, the reduced oxygen levels lead to decreased conductance of potassium (K+) channels in the glomus cell membrane.
    • This is due to the hypoxia causing the K+ channels to close or become less active.
  2. Depolarisation:
    • The reduced K+ conductance decreases K+ efflux, resulting in the depolarisation of the glomus cell membrane.
    • This change in membrane potential makes the inside of the cell less negative.
  3. Calcium Influx:
    • Depolarisation opens voltage-gated L-type calcium (Ca2+) channels, allowing calcium ions to flow into the cell.
    • The influx of Ca2+ further depolarises the cell and initiates intracellular signalling.
  4. Dopamine Release:
    • The increased intracellular Ca2+ triggers the release of neurotransmitters, such as dopamine, from the glomus cell.
    • Dopamine is released into the synaptic cleft of the afferent nerve endings.
  5. Increased Ventilation:
    • Dopamine acts on the central nervous system by binding to D2 receptors in the medulla oblongata.
    • This signalling increases respiratory drive and ventilation (breathing rate and depth).

questions.text: Decreased arterial blood pressure leads to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increased ventilation

 

Explanation:

Decreased arterial blood pressure leads to increased ventilation by central and peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Peripheral Chemoreceptors

Central Chemoreceptors

Pathway

Decreased arterial pressure → decreased perfusion of peripheral tissues, including the carotid and aortic bodies → hypoxia (decreased oxygen levels) → stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors.

Decreased arterial pressure → reduced removal of carbon dioxide (CO2) → CO2 retention → increased arterial PCO2 → increased concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) due to the conversion of CO2 to HCO3- and H+ → stimulation of central chemoreceptors in the medulla.

Result

The peripheral chemoreceptors send signals to the respiratory centres in the brainstem to increase the rate and depth of breathing to improve oxygen delivery and restore homeostasis.

The central chemoreceptors also stimulate the respiratory centres to enhance ventilation, thereby increasing the elimination of CO2 and improving blood gas levels.

This dual mechanism ensures that the body responds promptly to a drop in arterial blood pressure by increasing ventilation, thereby improving oxygenation and CO2 clearance to maintain physiological balance.

 

Decreased ventilation (Option B) – Incorrect, as hypoxia and hypotension trigger compensatory mechanisms to increase, not decrease, ventilation.

No effect at all (Option C) – Incorrect, as the body responds to hypotension with increased respiratory drive via chemoreceptor activation.

Depends on the temperature (Option D) – Incorrect, as ventilation regulation is primarily controlled by blood gases and pH, not temperature.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient, Mr Kumar, is admitted to the hospital with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation. He appears short of breath and has a low oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals:

 

pH: 7.32

PaCO2: 55 mm Hg

PaO2: 55 mm Hg

HCO3-: 24 mmol/L

 

What will most likely activate Mr. Kumar's peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to hypoxia (PaO2 <60 mm Hg), hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mm Hg), and acidosis (pH <7.35).

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors:

 

Topic

Details

Location
  • Carotid bodies: At bifurcations of common carotid arteries
  • Aortic bodies: Along the ascending aorta and arch of the aorta

Function

Send signals to the dorsal respiratory group (DRG) in the medulla to increase ventilation

Carotid Bodies

Type I (glomus) cells and Type II (sustentacular) cells

Type I Cells (Glomus Cells)

Release dopamine in response to hypoxia, triggering an action potential in the carotid sinus nerve

Aortic Bodies

Contain glomus cells similar to carotid bodies but are less effective in regulating respiration

Responses
  • Hypoxia: Increased firing rate of afferent nerves when PaO2 < 60 mm Hg
  • Hypercapnia: Linear increase in chemoreceptor discharge rate with increased PaCO2
  • Acidosis: Stimulates ventilation independently of hypoxia and hypercapnia

questions.text: Where is the pneumotaxic centre, which regulates respiratory rate, located in the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pons


Explanation:

The pneumotaxic centre is part of the brain's respiratory control system and is located in the upper part of the pons. It maintains the rate of breathing.

 

The primary function of the pneumotaxic centre is to limit the duration of inspiration, thereby controlling the respiratory rate. Sending inhibitory signals to the inspiratory centre in the medulla oblongata helps prevent the lungs from overinflating.

 

Mechanism:

questions.text: The apneustic centre is inhibited by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pneumotaxic center

Explanation:

Apneustic center:

  • Located in the caudal pons
  • Stimulation results in prolonged inspiratory effort interrupted by brief expiration (apneusis)
  • Strongly activates the medullary inspiratory centre
  • Tonically inhibited by the pneumotaxic centre. It ensures that the inspiratory drive originating in the apneustic centre is regulated and checked.

questions.text: Which group of neurons is involved in controlling forceful expiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ventral respiratory group of neurons

Explanation: The Ventral Respiratory Group of neurons (VRG) in the medulla controls forceful expiration.

Ventral Respiratory Group of neurons (VRG):

  • When the need for increased pulmonary ventilation arises, signals spill over into the VRG neurons.
  • It contributes to the extra respiratory drive which is required.
  • Electrical stimulation of some neurons causes inspiration, while stimulation of others causes expiration.
  • It is crucial for providing powerful expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during forceful expiration.
  • This is important during activities requiring high levels of pulmonary ventilation (heavy exercise).

questions.text: What is the structure responsible for the voluntary control of respiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cerebral cortex

Explanation:

  • The cerebral cortex is the outermost layer of the brain, involved in various higher-order brain functions such as sensation, voluntary muscle movement, thought, reasoning, and memory.
  • The primary motor cortex, located in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe, plays a key role in voluntary movements, including the voluntary control of breathing.
  • The voluntary control of respiration originates in the motor cortex and involves the corticospinal tract. This pathway directly sends signals from the cerebral cortex to the spinal cord, bypassing the brainstem respiratory centres.
  • Through this pathway, individuals can consciously control their breathing, such as holding their breath, taking a deep breath, or altering the breathing pattern during speech and singing.
  • While the brainstem (specifically the medulla and pons) is primarily responsible for the automatic, rhythmic breathing pattern, the cerebral cortex can override these automatic signals when exercising voluntary control.
  • This voluntary control is critical during activities requiring conscious modulation of breathing, such as talking, singing, playing wind instruments, or deliberate breath-holding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was involved in a severe motor vehicle accident resulting in multiple injuries, including a traumatic brain injury. Imaging studies revealed a complete transection of the brain stem below the medulla. Given this anatomical disruption, what would be the most likely effect on the patient's respiratory activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spontaneous but irregular respiration

 

Explanation:

 

Effects of various lesions and brainstem transections:

 

Level of transection

Vagus intact

Vagus cut

A

Complete transection above the pons

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues; the depth of inspiration increases.

B

Mid-pontine level section

Apneusis

C

Transection midway between the pons and the medulla

Irregular and rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below the medulla

Cessation of spontaneous respiration

 

Hyperventilation (Option B) is typically associated with lesions in the pons, particularly affecting the pneumotaxic centre, which helps regulate the rate and pattern of breathing.

 

Apneustic breathing (Option C) is characterised by prolonged inspiratory phases, is typically caused by damage to the apneustic centre in the lower pons. Since the transection is below the pons, it is unlikely to result in apneustic breathing.

 

Cheyne-Stokes respiration (Option D) involves periodic breathing with cycles of increasing and decreasing tidal volumes followed by periods of apnea. This pattern is usually associated with bilateral cortical or diencephalic damage, congestive heart failure, or high altitude.

questions.text: Ondine's curse, or Ondine's syndrome, is a rare disorder of the respiratory control centre. Which of the following is true about Ondine's curse?

choices.text: Loss of voluntary, but intact automatic control
Loss of automatic, but intact voluntary control
Loss of both automatic and voluntary control

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of autonomic, but intact voluntary control

 

Explanation:

Ondine's curse, also known as congenital central hypoventilation syndrome (CCHS), involves a failure of the autonomic regulation of breathing, leading to episodes of hypoventilation or hypoxia and requiring the individual to remember to breathe consciously.

 

Cause: Failure in autonomic regulation of breathing, often congenital or acquired due to brainstem damage.

Symptoms: Difficulty breathing during sleep, leading to sleep apnea or hypoventilation. Symptoms may not be present while awake.

Diagnosis: Sleep studies (polysomnography) to monitor and identify disruptions in breathing during sleep.

Treatment: Positive pressure ventilation devices like CPAP or BiPAP to maintain adequate ventilation during sleep.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the primary pacemaker for respiration in the brainstem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pre-Bötzinger Complex

Explanation:

The Ventral Respiratory Group consist of 4 clear zones.

 

Zones

Location

Function

Pre-Bötzinger Complex

Ventrolateral medulla

A primary pacemaker for respiration that generates the basic rhythmic pattern of breathing.

Bötzinger Complex

(Option B ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, dorsal

Modulates respiratory rhythm; involved in expiratory phase regulation and inhibition of inspiration.

Rostral Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option A ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, rostral

It contributes to rhythm generation and integrates respiratory signals; it is involved in the inspiratory and expiratory phases.

Caudal Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

(Option D ruled out)

Medulla oblongata, caudal

Primarily involved in controlling the expiratory phase of respiration.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describes the functions of the dorsal respiratory group (DRG) of neurons in the medulla?


	The DRG primarily regulates the rhythmic pattern of breathing.
	The DRG receives sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors and baroreceptors.
	The DRG mainly influences the expiratory phase of respiration.
	The DRG integrates information from the vagus nerve to adjust breathing depth.
	The DRG controls voluntary breathing movements during speech.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Statements 2 and 4 are correct

 

Explanation:

 

Feature

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Location

Medulla oblongata, primarily in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS)

Medulla oblongata, ventrolateral region, including nucleus ambiguus and nucleus retroambiguus

Primary Function

Controls basic rhythmic breathing; initiates and regulates respiration

Modulates rhythm and force of breathing; involved in complex breathing patterns

Breathing Pattern

Generates and maintains rhythmic breathing; primarily active during inspiration

Modifies breathing patterns; active during both inspiration and expiration

Connection with Other Centers

Integrates sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors and baroreceptors to adjust breathing

Coordinates with pneumotaxic and apneustic centres; adjust breathing for varying demands

Sensory Input

Receives input from lung stretch receptors and chemoreceptors detecting CO₂ and O₂ levels and integrates information from the vagus nerve to adjust breathing depth

Receives input from higher brain centres

Effect on Breathing

Establishes and regulates basic breathing rhythm; adjusts rate and depth

Fine-tune breathing patterns and force; adjust breathing during different activities

 

Statement 1 (Incorrect): The DRG primarily regulates the rhythmic breathing.

  • This function is primarily associated with the ventral respiratory group (VRG).

 

Statement 3 (Incorrect): The DRG mainly influences the expiratory phase of respiration.

  • The DRG is more involved in the inspiratory than the expiratory phase.

 

Statement 5 (incorrect): The DRG controls voluntary breathing movements during speech.

  • Voluntary breathing movements, such as those involved in speech, are primarily controlled by higher brain centres.

questions.text: Which of the following controls the depth of breathing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pneumotaxic center

 

Explanation:

The apneustic center  sends signals to the dorsal respiratory group to initiates and prolongs inspiration but Pneumotaxic center inhibits the apneustic center ,ends inspiration & begins  passive expiration .Thus pneumotaxic center modulates depth of breathing.

 

Mechanism:
